factoid: The enemy is far away.
Kutúzov exclaimed "The dispositions!".
Kutúzov asked who told you that.
Kutúzov told someone to do as ordered.
The person responded "Yes, sir".
Nesvítski whispered to Prince Andrew that the old man is as surly as a dog.
An Austrian officer in a white uniform with green plumes in his hat galloped up to Kutúzov.
The Austrian officer asked in the Emperor’s name if the fourth column had advanced into action.
Kutúzov turned around without answering.
Kutúzov's eye fell upon Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew was beside Kutúzov.
Kutúzov's expression softened when he saw Prince Andrew.
Kutúzov addressed Bolkónski.
Kutúzov did not answer the Austrian adjutant.
Kutúzov told Bolkónski to go and see whether the third division had passed the village.
Kutúzov told Bolkónski to tell the third division to stop and await his orders.
Prince Andrew started moving but then stopped.
Prince Andrew asked whether sharpshooters had been posted.
Prince Andrew murmured "What are they doing?" to himself.
Prince Andrew did not reply to the Austrian.
Prince Andrew galloped off to execute Kutúzov's order.
Prince Andrew stopped the third division.
Prince Andrew convinced himself that there were no sharpshooters in front of our columns.
Prince Andrew overrode the battalions that continued to advance.
The colonel at the head of the regiment was surprised at the commander in chief’s order to throw out skirmishers.
The colonel felt sure that there were other troops in front of him.
The colonel believed the enemy must be at least six miles away.
There was nothing to be seen in front except a barren descent hidden by dense mist.
Prince Andrew gave orders in the commander in chief’s name to rectify this omission.
Prince Andrew galloped back.
Kutúzov sat yawning wearily with closed eyes.
Kutúzov was in the same place.
Kutúzov’s body was stout and rested heavily in the saddle.
Kutúzov had the lassitude of age.
The troops were not moving.
The troops stood with the butts of their muskets on the ground.
Kutúzov said "All right, all right!" to Prince Andrew.
Kutúzov turned to a general.
The general had a watch in hand.
The general said it was time to start as all the left-flank columns had already descended.
Kutúzov muttered "Plenty of time, your excellency" while yawning.
Kutúzov repeated "Plenty of time.".
The sound of regiments saluting was heard behind Kutúzov.
The sound rapidly came nearer along the whole extended line of the advancing Russian columns.
The person they were greeting was riding quickly.
When the soldiers of the regiment in front of Kutúzov began to shout, Kutúzov rode a little to one side.
Kutúzov looked round with a frown.
A squadron of horsemen galloped along the road from Pratzen.
Two horsemen rode side by side in front at full gallop.
One horseman wore a black uniform with white plumes in his hat and rode a bobtailed chestnut horse.
The other horseman wore a white uniform and rode a black horse.
The two horsemen were the Emperors followed by their suites.
Kutúzov gave the command "Attention!".
Kutúzov rode up to the Emperors with a salute.
Kutúzov affected the manners of an old soldier at the front.
Kutúzov’s appearance and manner were suddenly transformed.
Kutúzov put on the air of a subordinate who obeys without reasoning.
Kutúzov had an affectation of respect that struck Alexander unpleasantly.
Kutúzov rode up and saluted.
The unpleasant impression flitted over the young and happy face of the Emperor like a cloud of haze across a clear sky and vanished.
After his illness, he looked rather thinner that day than on the field of Olmütz where Bolkónski had seen him for the first time abroad.
He still had the same bewitching combination of majesty and mildness in his fine gray eyes.
He had the same capacity for varying expression on his delicate lips.
He had the same prevalent appearance of goodhearted innocent youth.
